answer:
<analysis>

Below is a worked‐through explanation showing why the lone through‐lane is the left lane, with the right lane marked as turn‐only.

</analysis>

Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:

• Frame 1 & 2:  
  – Two main lanes appear in the driver’s direction. Road markings are not yet very clear at a distance, but you can see the dashed center line solidly dividing what look to be two through lanes.  
  – No obvious “ONLY” text is visible yet, so it is too soon to conclude each lane’s destination (straight or turn).

• Frame 3 & 4:  
  – A white regulatory sign emerges on the left side with two separate arrows (one curving left, one going straight). This sign typically indicates the left lane is associated with left‐turn movement (arrow curving) and the right lane is for traveling straight (the upward arrow). However, because it is a single sign with two separate arrows, it most often denotes “one lane for left turns” and “another lane for straight” rather than a single lane that can do both.  
  – Meanwhile, ground markings still are not fully legible in these frames, so the definitive “turn‐only” marking is not yet obvious.

• Frame 5 (most revealing):  
  – The right lane has large white pavement text “ONLY” and a turn arrow. This means the right lane is right‐turn‐only at the intersection.  
  – The left lane does not show any “ONLY” marking. In the absence of a “LEFT ONLY” marking (or any additional sign specifically forbidding going straight), traffic convention is that this left lane continues straight (and likely also permits left turns if needed).

Contextual Reasoning:

By the final approach (Frame 5), the pavement clearly shows “ONLY” in the right lane with a right‐turn arrow. Since that lane must turn right, the only lane from which you can legally continue straight is the left lane.

Match to Answer Choices:

• A (0 lanes straight) is inconsistent with standard lane usage—there is plainly a left lane that continues through.  
• B (1 lane straight) matches the evident markings: the left lane is unmarked as “ONLY” and therefore serves through traffic, while the right lane is a “right‐turn‐only.”  
• C (2 lanes straight) is contradicted by the “ONLY” marking in the right lane.

Thus, the best single answer is that there is one lane (the left lane) from which you can proceed straight.

<answer>B</answer>
